pros: I worked for Centegra for almost 10 years.  In the beginning, it was great.  They gave fair raises, had pretty decent benefits and I was a satisfied employee.   It was really a dream job for the first couple of years.
cons: As time has gone on, upper management has slowly eroded what made it a smooth running, friendly place to work.  The bottom line, profit, has become the one and only purpose of Centegra, not patient care.  They have sacrificed patient care and the morale of their employees, all so the executives can pay themselves exorbitant bonuses.  They dissolved the entire medical records department and sold us, in toto, to a low paying, service rather than doing the right thing by paying us severance and unemployment.

pros: Great people to work with

review_title: Centegra supports management that bullies and degrades their employees.
pros: I participated in many councils and led a system wide one. Had an impression this hospital was for their nurses....
cons: A new manager who was promoted to the role, dislike some of the current staff. Took advantage of the role by bulling and harassing employees. I was bullied frequently and ultimately fired (with my children present, which they knew would be with me) for "not managing up the unit", when I informed another employee I was unable to get a hold of anyone able to cover my lunch so I was going to run down and be right back. I was called in and harassed for 1 hour. HR was always made aware of each interaction. I was worked for more 15 days before I was called in on my vacation to be terminated for the above incident. I fought for unemployment and won. The judge agreed I was fired for reason other than what was on my termination paper. They appealed and again lost. Many others have be terminated and resigned for similar issues.

pros: I worked at the health club facility of Centegra and the members are wonderful!  They made it worth working there each day. cons: Management.  If you love being at work and not having a family or social life, then this is a place for you. Family doesn't matter to Centegra - work is the only thing that matters!  You have all this PTO and you can't even use it!  So at the end of the year, it's added to your  paycheck because you'll lose it if  it's not used.  The benefits stunk, too!  Expensive and not worth it!  You are  actually better off going on your own!  Also, if you want to make it there, you need to  do a lot of  brown-nosing to your manager!  If not, you are over-looked for job opportunities . . . regardless of whether  you are better qualified or have more seniority.  In the end, you put all this time and effort into your job, it's still not  good enough!  It's all about stroking egos!

pros: Taking care of my patients, sharing stories and making them smile

They do not care at all about patient care. They do not live the values of the hospital.

review_title: Administration does not care about employees or safety of patients.

The COO reports to her daddy, the CEO.  That should say it all.  She hardly has to be competent because she certainly won't be fired.  Nepotism and the "good ole boy" network is the culture and style of Centegra.  That accounts for the high turnover and poor morale.  The business culture is full of  inefficiencies, poor decision making, discrimination, poor skill sets, and lack of motivation.  Run in the other direction--do not consider this place for employment. Check the ratings of other local hospitals and you will see a huge difference.  I am so glad I am no longer in the oppressive environment.

review_title: Constantly changing, not always for the better.

review_title: Not the best, not the worst.
pros: I came into Centegra as a temp, and was hired on in the scheduling and pre-reg department. I was there a total of 5 years. The benefits were amazing, the pay was fantastic. I was not a fan of working the night hours but it was a job. My co-workers were good people to work with. The job itself was not bad, it could be stressful, but I had a high degree of satisfaction from my work.
cons: We worked in a closed basement room. Which meant, if one person got sick, EVERYONE got sick. The air quality was terrible down there. Because of this, I was sick EVERY 8 WEEKS. It was terrible. And of course, if I got sick, I brought it home to my kids. It was not just me, other employees had the same issues. Maintenance came in and did air quality readings and said the air flow was fine, but it really was not. Because of the constant illness, I missed a lot of work, something that never happened at my previous jobs. Another con was that upper management liked to spring new things on us. It was constant adding departments we were scheduling and then taking them away, and it never felt like we had enough real training to schedule certain department. There was also no real room for advancement. You could transfer into a different department, but it meant taking a hefty pay cut. So, you were stuck where you were.

pros: The people  are the strength of this system. They care about their patients and each other.  Nursing strives to give good patient care when staffed adequately to do so.
cons: Upper management is top heavy and does not seem to understand or care about the bedside care givers.  The decisions made are based on reimbursements and if that is reflective  of patient satisfaction then it is a priority  otherwise no. it's as if we are a factory making widgets.

pros: Lower and mid level managers really do care about the employees and try to do their best but often are blocked by upper management

Health insurance premiums I felt ran high.

review_title: Former rn with 17 years of employment
pros: Dedicated care professionals at the bedside/hands on level. Management in the department I worked in was professional, experienced, approachable and not afraid to pitch in and had good to exceptional understanding and ability to perform any task/ job in the department.  Most workers give 150% and that should be recognized as the reason this system has survived. Direct care providers have not lost their dedication to providing excellent care.
cons: The significant abrupt change in the last three years in the approach of executive management from a caring patient focused, experienced team to  key leaders having little to no experience in departments they are leading, targeting more experienced if they don't begin to conform to the click's attitude is emotionally and professionally draining. Nepotism should have no place in a health care company unless you bring the experience and knowledge with you.  Structural changes have caused many fine dedicated people to leave or be forced out. Adequate staffing should balance experienced team members with newer grads to continue with good patient care while continuing to build a solid team for the future.  The rush to get an EMR so you can take advantage of government funds has likely cost the company a lot. The inadequacy of those who were handed the responsibility to build it has caused a number of unsafe practices, tedious work to even get the right information about patients, errors or negligent care and showed a complete lack of understanding of daily work processes and impact on care. Revamping teams that require certain skills and medical experience  with inadequate experience or no experience and who don't understand their role, are not qualified  and are defensive doesn't solve anything.
